para.text: This chapter applies to all units of State and local government that construct projects subject to the Coast Smart Construction Program.
This chapter does not apply to the reconstruction of a highway facility.
In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
The following terms have the meaning stated in Natural Resources Article, §3-1001, Annotated Code of Maryland:
“Coast Smart”;
“Coast Smart Council”;
“Design criteria”;
“Siting criteria”;
“Structure”; and
“Substantial damage”.

“Categorical Exemption” means an exemption from the strict application of the Coast Smart siting or design criteria for a class of projects, provided the project has been designed to include adaptation and resiliency features to prevent or mitigate damage to the maximum extent practicable.
“Coast Smart Map” means the map adopted by the Coast Smart Council delineating the boundary within which the Coast Smart Construction Program applies.
Coast Smart Construction Program.

“Coast Smart Construction Program” means the program that establishes Coast Smart siting and design criteria for the construction of new or reconstructed structures and new highway facilities within the boundary established by the Coast Smart Map.
“Coast Smart Construction Program” includes the Coast Smart Map and the Coast Smart Construction Program Document, adopted by the Coast Smart Council
Critical or Essential Facilities.
“Critical or essential facilities” means buildings and other structures that are intended to remain operational in the event of extreme environmental impacts from flood, wind, snow, or earthquakes.

“Critical and essential facilities” include hospitals, fire stations, police stations, storage of critical records, facilities that handle or store hazardous materials, drinking water and sewage treatment facilities, airports, transit and highway access and other essential transportation, and similar facilities.
“Emergency” has the meaning stated in Public Safety Article, §14-101, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Historic structure” means a structure that is located in the State and:
Is listed in the National Register of Historic Places;
Is designated as a historic property under local law and determined by the Director of the Maryland Historical Trust to be eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places; or
Is:

Located in a historic district listed on the National Register of Historic Places or in a local historic district that the Director of the Maryland Historical Trust determines is eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places; and
Certified by the Director of the Maryland Historical Trust as contributing to the significance of the district.
“Passive public access project” means a project that:
Provides either recreational or scenic access to water bodies or shoreline areas; and
Requires location within a flood zone for its purpose.
“Qualifying agency” means a unit of state or local government that funds, plans, designs, constructs, or oversees capital projects subject to the Coast Smart Construction Program.
“Temporary structure” means a structure intended to be in place for less than 180 consecutive days in any given calendar year.
“Water-dependent project” means a project that by reason of its intrinsic nature or operation is:
Dependent on the water;
Requires location at or near the water; and
Requires continued direct access to the water as an integral part of its use.
A project shall comply with the Coast Smart Construction Program if it meets the criteria in §B of this regulation.
The applicable Coast Smart Construction Program criteria are:
The project is a capital project;
The project is located within the Coast Smart boundary, as indicated on the Coast Smart Map;
The project includes:
The construction of a new structure;
The reconstruction of a structure with substantial damage; or
The construction of a new highway facility;
At least 50 percent of the total project costs are funded with state funds; and
The total project cost is $500,000 or more.

Projects subject to the Coast Smart Construction Program shall satisfy the Coast Smart siting and design criteria specified in the Coast Smart Construction Program Document published on the Department’s website.
For all projects subject to the Coast Smart Construction Program, the Qualifying Agency shall complete the Coast Smart Project Screening Form within the Coast Smart Construction Program Document.
The following categories of projects may be exempt from the strict application of the Coast Smart siting and design criteria:
Water-dependent projects;
Passive public access projects;
Historic structures;
Temporary structures; and
Emergency projects.

A qualifying agency may determine that a project qualifies for a categorical exemption, provided that the qualifying agency demonstrates that the project has been designed to include adaptation and resiliency features to prevent or mitigate damage to the maximum extent practicable.

For all projects eligible for a categorical exemption, the qualifying agency must complete the Coast Smart Project Screening Form within the Coast Smart Construction Program Document and indicate the project category for which the exemption applies.
The qualifying agency may request input from the Coast Smart Council regarding the project’s eligibility for and the qualifying agency’s determination of an exemption.
The qualifying agency shall make the final determination as to whether a project qualifies for an exemption.
The qualifying agency shall provide the completed Coast Smart Project Screening Form to the Coast Smart Council upon request.
A qualifying agency may request a waiver from one or more of the Coast Smart siting or design criteria.
The Governor's Sustainable Growth Subcabinet, established under State Government Article, § 9-1403, Annotated Code of Maryland, shall review and decide waiver requests.
The qualifying agency shall submit to the Governor's Sustainable Growth Subcabinet:
The Coast Smart Criteria Waiver Form within the Coast Smart Construction Program Document;
All necessary supporting documents including the Coast Smart Project Screening Form; and
A letter:
Identifying the specific siting or design criteria from which a waiver is requested;
Justification for why the project is unable to meet the Coast Smart siting or design criteria; and
Factors upon which the waiver request is based, as provided in the Coast Smart Construction Program Document.
Upon request, a qualifying agency shall submit project information to the Coast Smart Council.
The information shall include the following list of projects:
Projects that were located within the Coast Smart boundary, as indicated on the Coast Smart Map;
Projects for which the qualifying agency made a categorical exemption determination; and
Projects that received waiver determinations from the Governor's Sustainable Growth Subcabinet.
The qualifying agency shall maintain all project information, including the Coast Smart Screening Form, in accordance with the agency's document retention schedule.

para.text: The Board may restore the license of an individual who has failed to renew the license for any reason if the individual:
Applies for restoration within 4 years of expiration of the license;
Otherwise is entitled to be licensed; and
Pays to the Board the renewal fee.
An individual who fails to seek the restoration of a license within 4 years days of expiration of the license shall:
File a written letter with the Board providing:
The reasons the individual permitted the license to expire,
An explanation for the individual's failure to file a timely application for license renewal or restoration,
A statement of the individual's employment and job duties since the license expiration, and
Any documentation to support the individual's claims; and
Appear in person before the Board to show good and valid cause why the individual's license should be restored, if the Board requires the individual to do so.
The Board may:
Restore an expired license of the applicant under this regulation if the applicant:
Is otherwise entitled to be licensed, and
Pays to the Board all past due renewal fees, and any applicable reinstatement and late fees;
Require the applicant to pay the applicable examination fees, and take and successfully pass the written examination required for the license previously held by the applicant; or

Consider the applicant as having never been licensed, in accordance with Business Regulation Article, §9A-309(e)(2), Annotated Code of Maryland, thus requiring the filing of a new application and complying with Business Regulation Article, §9A-302, Annotated Code of Maryland.

para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
“Administrative fee” means the fee due and owing on an employer's taxable wage base under §8-605.1 of the Unemployment Insurance Law.
“Contributor” means an employing unit liable for contributions on taxable wages for covered employment.
“Covered employment” means service performed for an employing unit that is subject to the Unemployment Insurance Law as determined by the Secretary.
“Department” means the Maryland Department of Labor.
“Reimburser” means a nonprofit organization or governmental unit, as defined in the Unemployment Insurance Law, that elects to finance its Unemployment Insurance liability through self-insurance.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Labor or the Secretary's designee.
“Unemployment Insurance Law” means Labor and Employment Article, Title 8, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Unless the context indicates otherwise, all other terms used in this chapter shall have the same meanings as in the Unemployment Insurance Law or in COMAR 09.32.02.
Registration. An employer shall file a registration application with the Comptroller of the Treasury within 20 days after the first day the business begins operation.
Further Information.
Additional or supplemental reports to determine liability shall be filed at the Secretary's request.
An employer that contends it is not liable under the Unemployment Insurance Law shall submit to the Secretary information to support that contention.
Determination. The Secretary shall review the registration application and any additional or supplemental reports to determine the employer's liability pursuant to the Unemployment Insurance Law.
Review. An employing unit that disputes the liability determination may seek review of the determination pursuant to Labor and Employment Article, §8-604, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Contributor.

Benefit Payments Charged. Except as provided in §A(2) of this regulation or in the Unemployment Insurance Law, the earned-rate record of a contributor who is a base period employer shall be charged with all regular and work-sharing benefit payments, the appropriate share of extended benefit payments, and dependents' allowance.
Benefit Payments Not Chargeable. Benefit payments may not be charged against the earned-rate record of a contributor who is a base period employer when the claimant:
Voluntarily left employment:
Without good cause,
To accept better employment, or
To enter a training program approved by the Secretary;
Has been discharged by the employer for gross misconduct as defined in the Unemployment Insurance Law;
Was employed by the employing unit on a continuous part-time basis as of the date of the claimant’s initial claim for benefits; or
Was employed in a work release program as set forth in the Unemployment Insurance Law, if the separation was caused by the claimant's release from prison.
Continuous Part-Time Basis. For the purposes of this regulation, employment is on a continuous part-time basis under Labor and Employment Article, Title 8, Subtitle 6, Annotated Code of Maryland if:
The claimant was not employed by the employing unit on a full-time basis during the base period;
The claimant continued to be employed by the employing unit on a part-time basis as of the date of the initial claim for benefits; and
The employing unit did not cause the claimant’s part-time working hours to be reduced.
When Charged.
Benefit payments shall be charged to an employer's earned-rate record for the calendar quarter during which the benefits are paid.
A notice of benefit payments charged to the contributor's earned-rate record shall be sent to the contributor at the end of each calendar quarter.

Benefit Overpayment Credit. When an overpayment of benefits is established, the overpayment shall be credited to the contributor's earned-rate record in the calendar quarter in which the overpayment is established.
Reimburser.

A reimburser who is a base period employer shall reimburse the Unemployment Insurance Trust Fund for all regular and work-sharing benefit payments, the appropriate share of extended benefit payments, and dependents' allowance.
A notice of benefit payments that must be reimbursed (Statement of Reimbursable Benefits) shall be sent to the reimburser at the end of each calendar quarter.
Allocation.
Reimbursers and Contributors.

When not all of the claimant's base period employers are reimbursers, benefits paid to a claimant shall first be allocated to each reimburser in accordance with the Unemployment Insurance Law. The remainder of the claimant's benefit payments shall be charged to the earned-rate record of those base period employers who are contributors in the same ratio that each employer paid the claimant's total base period wages.
When calculating the allocation, the percentage of the charge to each base period employer shall be rounded off to the nearest whole number.
Contributors. When all the claimant's base period employers are contributors, benefits paid to a claimant shall be allocated to each contributor in accordance with the Unemployment Insurance Law.
Reimbursers. When all the claimant's base period employers are reimbursers, benefits paid to a claimant shall be prorated to each reimburser in accordance with the Unemployment Insurance Law.

Charging of Out-of-State Benefit Payments. Except as provided in §A(2) of this regulation, when the State reimburses another state for benefits paid by that other state based on Maryland wages, the earned-rate record of each contributor shall be charged, and each reimburser shall be charged in the same ratio that each employer paid the claimant's total Maryland wages.
Review. An employer who disputes the charging determination may seek review of the determination pursuant to Labor and Employment Article, §8-604, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Responsibility of Employing Unit.

An employing unit shall record the Social Security number of each of its employees. If an employee does not have a Social Security number, the employing unit shall require the employee to execute the proper application form to acquire a Social Security number within 5 days of the first day of employment.
Employment Records.

An employing unit shall keep employment records safe and readily accessible at the place of business of the employing unit. The records shall be retained and preserved for a period of 5 years from the last day of the calendar quarter to which the records relate.

An employing unit that discontinues business shall keep employment records safe and readily accessible. The records shall be retained and preserved for a period of 5 years from the last day of the calendar quarter to which the records relate.

Employment records include but are not limited to wage records, payroll registers, check registers, cash disbursements journals, cancelled checks, federal income tax returns (Schedule 1040C for individual proprietors), forms 1096 and 1099, and general ledgers.
Employment records shall be made available to the Department for inspection and copying. Prior notice to the employing unit is not required.
Specific Contents of Wage Records. An employing unit shall include in its wage records:
The dates of each pay period;
All of the wages paid to each worker for each pay period and the total amount of wages paid for employment in the pay period, showing separately the amount of wages paid:
In cash; and
In any medium other than cash;
The method by which wages are computed;
Hire date, separation date, and reason for separation of each worker;
Name, address, and Social Security number of each worker; and
With respect to individuals who work less than full-time:
The wage rate;
The number of hours worked each day;
Wages earned by calendar week;
Whether the individual worked less than full-time during the week; and
Whether the individual worked all available hours.
Contributions and administrative fees are due and shall be paid on or before the last day of the month immediately following each calendar quarter.

Contributions and administrative fees from an employer whose status is changed by cessation of business, or appointment of a receiver, trustee, trustee in bankruptcy, or other fiduciary are due and shall be paid within 5 days of the change in status.
For payment of administrative fees, a fractional part of a cent:
That is less than one-half cent shall be disregarded; and
That is one-half cent or more shall be increased to 1 cent.
Failure to pay the required contributions in the prescribed manner shall result in the imposition of interest charges as provided in Labor and Employment Article, §8-628, Annotated Code of Maryland.

Failure to pay the required administrative fees in the prescribed manner shall result in the imposition of interest charges as provided in Labor and Employment Article §8-628, Annotated Code of Maryland, for the nonpayment of contributions.
The Secretary shall pay interest collected on administrative fees into the Special Administrative Expense Fund established under Labor and Employment Article, §8-419, Annotated Code of Maryland.

section.heading: Collection of Administrative Fees and Interest.

para.text: Collection by Assessment.
If an employing unit fails to pay administrative fees or related interest due based on information the employing unit provided in a contribution report, the Secretary:
May assess the amount of the payment or interest due as prescribed under Labor and Employment Article, §8-629, Annotated Code of Maryland, for the nonpayment of contributions; and
Notwithstanding §(2) of this regulation, may make an additional assessment if the contribution report is later determined to be incorrect.
An assessment under this regulation is final unless:
An employing unit requests a review determination under Labor and Employment Article, §8-604, Annotated Code of Maryland; or
On its own motion, the Board of Appeals grants a hearing to consider whether the amount should be reduced.

Except in the case of a fraudulent contribution report or the failure to file a contribution report, written notice of an assessment under this regulation shall be sent to an employing unit within 3 years of the last day of the period at issue in the notice.

If an employing unit fails to pay an assessment under this regulation, the Secretary may file a notice of lien in the circuit court of the county where the employing unit’s principal place of business is located, or a notice of lien in any other county that includes the information set forth in Labor and Employment Article, §8-629, Annotated Code of Maryland.
If, after an assessment, an employing unit fails to pay administrative fees or interest, the Secretary may collect the amount due by filing a civil action or pursuing any other available legal means.
A contributor shall file with the Secretary, on or before the contribution payment date, a complete and correct contribution report containing:
Total quarterly wages paid by the contributor;
Taxable quarterly wages paid by the contributor;
Total wages in excess of $8,500 per year;
Computation of contributions and administrative fees due;
The employing unit's Maryland unemployment insurance account number;
The employing unit's tax rate applicable to the quarter filed;
The number of employees performing services for the employing unit in each month of the quarter;
If applicable, penalties or interest as set forth in the Unemployment Insurance Law;
The signature of the employing unit or authorized representative; and
Other information the Secretary may require.
Contribution reports shall be filed by an employing unit that operates its business during a calendar quarter, even though no wages were paid during that quarter.
Exceptions to Filing Date.
An employing unit that transfers its business to another employer shall file a contribution report within 15 days from the date of discontinuation or transfer.

An employing unit who otherwise discontinues its business or whose status is changed by appointment of a receiver, trustee, trustee in bankruptcy, or other fiduciary, shall file a contribution report within 5 days from the date of this change in status.
An employing unit shall file with the Secretary on or before the contribution payment date, a complete and correct employment report containing:
Name and Social Security number of each employee;
The employing unit's Maryland unemployment insurance account number;
Total quarterly wages paid to each employee;
Total quarterly wages paid by the employing unit; and
Other information the Secretary may require.
Exceptions to Filing Date.
An employing unit that transfers its business to another employer shall file an employment report within 15 days from the date of the discontinuation or transfer.

An employing unit that otherwise discontinues its business or whose status is changed by appointment of a receiver, trustee, trustee in bankruptcy, or other fiduciary, shall file an employment report within 5 days from the date of this change in status.
Penalties.
Contribution Reports. An employing unit that fails to file a timely contribution report in the prescribed manner shall pay a penalty of $35.
Employment Reports. An employing unit that fails to file a timely employment report in the prescribed manner shall pay a penalty of $35.
Separation Reports. An employing unit that fails to file a timely separation report in the prescribed manner upon the Secretary's request shall pay a penalty of $15.
Earnings Reports. An employing unit that fails to file a timely earnings report in the prescribed manner upon the Secretary's request shall pay a penalty of $15.
An employing unit that submits a check or other negotiable instrument that is returned for insufficient funds shall pay a penalty of $25.

Interest on Past Due Contributions and Administrative Fees. An employing unit that fails to file a timely contribution report shall pay interest on contributions and administrative fees then due and unpaid at a rate in accordance with Regulation .09 of this chapter until the contribution report and payment is received.
The Secretary may waive any penalties or interest for cause, upon the employer's request or upon the Secretary's review of the penalty or interest assessed.

section.heading: Order of Payments.
section.text: A payment made by an employing unit shall be applied in the following order to an amount due and owing at the time of payment:

para.text: To any penalty imposed;
To any interest due and owing on administrative fees;
To any interest due and owing on contributions and reimbursement payments;
To administrative fees; and
To contributions or reimbursement payments.
Application for refunds and adjustments of contributions, reimbursement payments, or related interest shall be processed in accordance with the Unemployment Insurance Law.

Application for refunds and adjustments of administrative fees or related interest shall be processed in the manner set forth in the Unemployment Insurance Law for refunds and adjustments of contributions, except that the Secretary shall refund any such amounts erroneously collected from the Special Administrative Expense Fund.
Refunds.
Automatic Refund. In each quarter when the Secretary determines that a refund due an employing unit is less than $100, the Secretary shall automatically issue a refund to that employing unit.

In each quarter when the Secretary determines that a refund due an employing unit is $100 or over, the refund may be applied to the employing unit's future indebtedness or refunded at the employing unit's request.
Definitions.
For the purpose of this regulation, "related corporation" means a member of a controlled group of corporations as the term is defined in the Internal Revenue Code.

For purposes of this regulation, an individual is considered "concurrently employed" by two or more related corporations if the individual performs services for covered wages for the common paymaster for some portion of each calendar year.
Payment through Common Paymaster.

When two or more related corporations concurrently employ the same individual and compensate that individual through a common paymaster, and when the common paymaster is one of the related corporations that employs the individual, each corporation shall be considered to have paid only the remuneration it actually disburses to that individual. If all the remuneration to the individual from the related corporations is disbursed through the common paymaster, the total amount of wages disbursed by the common paymaster shall be deemed wages subject to contribution and administrative fees. The common paymaster shall be responsible for filing the contribution report and the employment report.

When two or more related corporations employ different individuals and compensate the individuals through a common paymaster, but the individual performs no service for the common paymaster during the calendar year, each corporation shall be considered to have paid only the remuneration it actually disburses to the individuals. The related corporations that pay the remuneration to the individuals shall each be responsible for filing the contribution reports and the employment reports.

The common paymaster shall notify the Secretary in writing, at least 30 days before the quarter for which the common paymaster reporting is to be effective, of the name and employer account number of each of the related corporations. The common paymaster shall notify the Secretary at least 30 days before any change or termination of the arrangement.

If the common paymaster fails to remit contributions and administrative fees due, the common paymaster and each of the other related corporations shall be jointly and severally liable for the full amount of the unpaid portion of the contributions and administrative fees.
Definition and Scope.
Definition. “Unemployment insurance tax preparer” means a person who files quarterly unemployment insurance contribution reports or employment reports on behalf of employing units for compensation.
Scope. Sections B and C of this regulation apply to unemployment insurance tax preparers who file on behalf of 100 or more employing units.
Method of Filing Contribution Reports and Employment Reports.
An unemployment insurance tax preparer shall file the information required in Regulations .11 and .12 of this chapter by mail or electronic means.
A contribution report or an employment report is deemed returned when it is either received by the Division of Unemployment Insurance or postmarked by the United States Post Office.

Method of Payment. An unemployment insurance tax preparer shall remit unemployment insurance contributions and administrative fees on behalf of employing units in one lump sum payment that covers in full the total contribution payments and administrative fees due for all the employing units that the preparer represents.

Penalty and Interest. An employing unit whose unemployment insurance tax preparer fails to file the contribution reports, employment reports, or pay contributions or administrative fees in the prescribed manner is subject to the penalties and interest set forth in Regulations .09 and .16 of this chapter and the Unemployment Insurance Law.
Professional Employer Organization.

"Professional employer organization" means an employing unit which places all or part of a client company's workers on its payroll or payrolls and, by written agreement, assigns or leases the workers to the client company.
"Professional employer organization" does not mean a temporary help firm within the meaning of this subtitle.
Obligations of a Professional Employer Organization.
A professional employer organization is subject to all of the rights and obligations of employing units under the Unemployment Insurance Law.
Acquisitions.
Upon the acquisition of all or part of a client company's workers:

A professional employer organization is initially classified as a successor employer for purposes of assigning a contribution rate, assessing administrative fees and tax liability, and transferring the taxable wage base of the workers who were placed on the professional employer organization's payroll; and
The client company is initially classified as a predecessor employer.

A subsequent acquisition or transfer, by sale or otherwise, of all or part of a professional employer organization's assets, business, organization, or trade is treated in accordance with the Unemployment Insurance Law.
Notification.
A professional employer organization shall notify the Secretary in writing when the company places all or part of a client company's workers on its payroll.
Notification shall be given within 30 days of placing the workers on the payroll and shall be provided in the form and manner required by the Secretary.
Notification shall include, at a minimum, the following information:
Name, address, and phone number of the professional employer organization;
Name, address, and phone number of the client company;
Date the professional employer organization acquired the client company's workers; and
Total number of workers acquired from the client company.
Annual Report.
On or before December 31 of each year, a professional employer organization shall file an annual report of the company's clients with the Secretary.
The annual report shall be in writing and shall include:
Name, address, and phone number of the professional employer organization; and
Names and addresses of client companies to whom the professional employer organization leases or assigns workers.

para.text: The Program covers the ABA services set forth in §B of this regulation when the services are:
Medically necessary;
Preauthorized by the Program or its designee;
Delivered in accordance with the participant's treatment plan; and
Supported by documentation of consent to treatment from the participant or the participant’s parent or guardian.
The Program covers the following ABA services:
An ABA assessment, which is a behavior identification assessment that:
Is administered in person with a participant and the participant's parent or caregiver by:
A licensed psychologist; or
An LBA;
Addresses the behavioral needs for ABA services; and
Includes:
An interview, direct observation, record review, data collection, and analysis;
An assessment of the participant's current level of functioning, skills deficits, and maladaptive behaviors using validated instruments;
Analysis of past data;
Scoring and interpreting the assessment;
Preparing the treatment plan and report; and
Discussion of the findings;
A behavior identification supporting assessment which is a follow-up assessment that is administered:
In person, by an RBT, BT, or BCaBA, with a participant present; and
Under the direction of a licensed psychologist or an LBA;
An exposure behavior identification supporting assessment which is a follow-up assessment that:
Is conducted on a participant with specific, severe destructive behaviors in a structured, safe environment;
Is administered in person by a licensed psychologist or an LBA with the assistance of two or more BCaBAs, RBTs, or BTs;
Exposes the participant to a customized series of social and environmental conditions associated with the destructive behaviors; and
Uses structured testing to examine events, cues, responses, and consequences associated with the behaviors;
An adaptive behavior treatment with protocol modification which is an in-person service that:

Safe;
Is administered in-person by a licensed psychologist or an LBA with the assistance of two or more BCaBAs, RBTs, or BTs;

A licensed psychologist; or
An LBA;
Identifies maladaptive behaviors and skills deficits;
Instructs parents or caregivers on how to utilize ABA treatments to reduce maladaptive behaviors and skill deficits; and

An LBA; or

Identifies maladaptive behaviors and skills deficits;
Instructs the parent or caregiver on how to utilize ABA strategies to reduce maladaptive behaviors and skill deficits; and
Is performed in person for at least 25 percent of the session time each month;

A licensed psychologist; or
An LBA;
Evaluates the progress toward each behavior treatment goal using objective, quantifiable measures and includes the results of validated instruments;
Includes a revision of the treatment plan based on progress; and
Includes a clinical recommendation as to whether ABA services continue to be medically necessary;
Group adaptive behavior treatment with protocol modification which is a service that is:
Provided in person to multiple participants by:
A licensed psychologist; or
An LBA;
Focused on social skills training; and
Aimed at identifying and targeting individual participants social deficits and maladaptive behaviors;
Adaptive behavior treatment direction of a technician which is the clinical direction and oversight of a BCaBA, RBT, or a BT by a licensed psychologist or an LBA that:
Requires the licensed psychologist or the LBA to directly or remotely observe the BCaBA, RBT, or BT administering ABA services to the participant, group of participants, parent, or caregiver;
Is performed on an ongoing basis, equal to at least 10 percent of the amount of hours that the BCaBA, RBT, or BT is providing direct ABA services to the participant, or group of participants; and
Is performed in person for at least 25 percent of the session time each month;
Adaptive behavior treatment by protocol which is an in-person service provided to a participant by:
A licensed psychologist or an LBA; or

A BCaBA, RBT, or BT under the direction of a licensed psychologist or an LBA utilizing a behavioral intervention designed in advance by the licensed psychologist or an LBA, who may or may not provide in-person or remote direction during the treatment; and
Adaptive behavior treatment planning which is an ongoing indirect service that:
Is performed by a licensed psychologist or an LBA; and
Includes:
Development and revision of the treatment plan and goals;
Data analysis; and
Real-time, direct communication and coordination with the participant's other service providers.
ABA services shall only be provided by a licensed psychologist, LBA, BCaBA, RBT, or BT.
ABA services shall be initially preauthorized for a period not to exceed 180 days.
Additional preauthorization beyond the initial preauthorization shall be requested every 180 days, in advance of the expiration of the previous preauthorization.
The provider shall maintain documentation of each service delivered under the participant's treatment plan, which, at a minimum, includes:
The location, date, start time, and end time of the service;
A brief description of the service provided, including reference to the treatment plan;

A description of the participant’s parent or caregiver’s participation in the ABA treatment sessions, including the parent or the caregiver’s name and relationship to the participant, date, and time of participation or notification of the participant’s parent or caregiver’s consent to be absent; and

para.text: In this subtitle, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
Accuracy or Accurate.
“Accuracy” or “accurate” means the degree of agreement between the determination of a quantity and its true value.
“Accuracy” or “accurate” includes the quality of a test result as it relates to the analytic phase of the testing process when the test result:
Conforms exactly to a standard; or
Deviates only within established limits from a standard.
“Alternative sanction” means a directed plan of correction or a limitation placed on testing.
“Analyte” means a substance or constituent for which a laboratory conducts testing.
“Analytical system” means a test system's methods, procedures, instruments, equipment, kits, reagents, and supporting materials used to detect or measure an analyte or perform a test.
Authorized Person.
“Authorized person” means an individual allowed to request a laboratory test.
“Authorized person” is limited to those individuals identified under COMAR 10.10.06.02.
“Buccal cavity” means the vestibule of the mouth, specifically the area lying between the teeth and cheeks.

“Buccal swab” means a specialized applicator with a sponge, cotton, or Dacron tip, used to collect epithelial cells for DNA testing by rubbing the applicator tip on the inside of the cheek in the buccal cavity.
“Calibrator” means a material having a known value or concentration that is used to standardize an analytical system.
“CDC” means the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
“Certified analyst” means an individual who:
Meets the qualifications established under COMAR 10.10.09.01B and .02C; and
Is thereby permitted to identify marijuana or marijuana products, or both, using procedures approved under COMAR 10.10.09.04.
“Certified chemical analyst” means an individual who:
Meets the qualifications established under COMAR 10.10.09.01A and .02B; and
Is thereby permitted to identify marijuana or marijuana products, or both, cocaine base, cocaine hydrochloride, and heroin using procedures approved under COMAR 10.10.09.04.
“Certified chemist” means an individual who:
Meets the qualifications established under COMAR 10.10.09.01A and .02A; and
Is thereby permitted to identify any controlled dangerous substance using procedures approved under COMAR 10.10.09.04.
“CFR” means the Code of Federal Regulations.
“CLIA” means the federal Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments of 1988 in Section 353 of the Public Health Service Act and any amendments to it (42 U.S.C. §263a).

“CLIA waived test” means a test system, assay, or examination that the federal Department of Health and Human Services has determined meets the Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA) statutory criteria as specified for waiver under the federal CLIA Amendments of 1988 in Section 353 of the Public Health Service Act of 42 U.S.C. §263a.
“CMS” means the federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.
“Collection station” means a site other than a laboratory where specimens are gathered before being shipped elsewhere for laboratory testing.
“Complaint investigation” means an investigation of a laboratory, including an on-site survey, initiated in response to a complaint.
“Control sample” means a material, solution, or lyophilized preparation used in laboratory quality control, the concentration of which is within certain specified and known limits.
“Controlled dangerous substance” means any drug, substance, or immediate precursor in Schedules I through V of Criminal Law Article, Title 5, Subtitle 4, Annotated Code of Maryland.
“Deficiency” means a situation or finding of statutory or regulatory noncompliance.
“Department” means the Maryland Department of Health.
“Directed plan of correction” means a set of corrective actions stipulated by the Secretary that a laboratory shall implement to effect statutory or regulatory compliance.
Discipline.
“Discipline” means a scientific field of study in which a laboratory is licensed to offer to perform or perform tests.
“Discipline” includes:
Chemistry, including the subdisciplines of blood gas analysis, endocrinology, radioimmunoassay, routine chemistry, toxicology, and urinalysis;

Forensic toxicology, including job-related alcohol and controlled dangerous substances, limited to the detection of alcohol or a controlled dangerous substance for a non-therapeutic or non-diagnostic, job-related purpose.
Genetics, including the subdisciplines of biochemical genetics, cytogenetics, medical genetics, and molecular genetics;
Health awareness testing, which is limited to health awareness tests set forth in §B(27) of this regulation;
Hematology, including the subdisciplines of coagulation testing, hemoglobinopathy screening, and routine hematology;
Immunology, including the subdisciplines of serology, immunohematology, and histocompatibility;
Microbiology, including the subdisciplines of bacteriology, mycobacteriology, mycology, parasitology, and virology;

Molecular biology, including nucleic acid probes; nucleic acid target, probe, and signal amplifications; recombinant nucleic acid techniques; and other techniques of applied molecular genetics other than cytogenetics used in connection with the diagnosis and control of human disease or the assessment of human health; and
Pathology, including the subdisciplines of gynecologic cytology, dermatopathology, and histopathology.
“Examinee” means an individual:
Whose specimen is collected or tested by a laboratory; or
Who is subject to a proficiency test in gynecologic cytology.
“Excepted laboratory” means a medical laboratory that offers to perform or performs tests limited to one or more excepted tests.
“Excepted test” means a medical laboratory test that is a CLIA waived test.
“Exfoliative” means falling off in scales or layers.
General Supervisor.
“General supervisor” means a technologist who possesses at least 4 years technical experience in a licensed medical laboratory other than an excepted laboratory.
“General supervisor” includes an individual who qualified as a supervisory technologist under previous State regulations.
“HDL-C” means high density lipoprotein cholesterol.
Health Awareness Test.
“Health awareness test” means a test approved by the Secretary to be performed at a temporary or mobile laboratory, such as a health fair in a shopping mall.
“Health awareness test” is limited to tests that:
Are performed solely for the purposes of screening for certain medical conditions and are not to be used for diagnostic or management of healthcare conditions;
Are performed on a CLIA waived testing device; and
Measure glucose, lipids, or other clinical values which the Secretary has concluded are in the interest of public health to be measured at a health awareness event.
“Immediate jeopardy” means a deficiency that poses immediate danger to public health or safety and requires the Secretary to take immediate action to remove the jeopardy.

“Immediate precursor” means a substance that the Department has found to be, and by regulation designates as being, the principal compound commonly used or produced primarily for use and that is an immediate chemical intermediary used or likely to be used in the manufacture of a controlled dangerous substance, the control of which is necessary to prevent, curtail, or limit that manufacture.
“Laboratory” means a medical laboratory.
“Letter of exception” means a license issued by the Secretary authorizing the operation of a laboratory to offer to perform or perform one or more excepted tests.

“Letter of exception—limited testing for rare diseases” means a license issued by the Secretary authorizing the operation of a laboratory to offer to perform or perform testing limited to one or more rare disease tests.
“License” means a permit, letter of exception, certificate, or other document issued by the Secretary granting approval or authority to:
Offer to perform or perform medical laboratory tests or examinations in this State;
Offer to perform or perform medical laboratory tests or examinations on specimens acquired from health care providers in this State at a medical laboratory located outside this State; or
Represent or service in this State a medical laboratory regardless of the laboratory's location.
“Licensed laboratory” means a laboratory operating under a license issued by the Secretary.
“Licensee” means a person who holds a license under this chapter to operate a laboratory.
“Limited public health testing” means testing limited to a combination of 15 or fewer excepted tests performed by a nonprofit organization or a State, county, or local health department.
“Marginal proficiency testing performance” means failure to attain the minimum satisfactory score for two of three consecutive proficiency testing events.
Medical Laboratory.
“Medical laboratory” means a facility, entity, or site that offers to perform or performs tests in connection with:
The diagnosis and control of human disease;
The assessment of human health, nutrition, or medical conditions; or
Job-related testing.
“Medical laboratory” includes but is not limited to a:
Physician office laboratory;
Point-of-care laboratory;
Laboratory owned or operated by the State, a county, or a municipal health department;
Not-for-profit laboratory;
Hospital laboratory; and
Commercial laboratory.
Method Verification.
“Method verification” means evaluation of an analytical system by assessment of each analytical system component, including instrument, test strip, cartridge, card, and kit reagent.
“Method verification” includes but is not limited to the determination of:
An analytical system's reportable range;
Accuracy; and
Within-run and run-to-run precision.
“Mobile laboratory” means a laboratory located in a moveable vehicle, such as a truck, trailer, van, or ambulance.

“Multi-site permit” means a permit available to the State, a county, or a municipal health department authorizing the operation of limited public health testing at more than one mobile or permanent laboratory.
“Office of Health Care Quality (OHCQ)” means the Office of Health Care Quality of the Maryland Department of Health, formerly the Licensing and Certification Administration (LCA).

“Operator of an analytical system” means an individual who applies a test specimen or control sample to an analytical system and performs the necessary operative steps to isolate or identify an infectious agent or measure an analyte.
“Owner” means a person who possesses a financial interest in a laboratory.
“Patient of the practice” means an individual who accepts referral to or is seen or otherwise examined by a member or members of a practice of medicine.
Permit.
“Permit” means a license issued by the Secretary authorizing a person to operate a medical laboratory conducting one or more tests that are not excepted tests.
“Permit” includes a:
Provisional permit; and
Temporary permit.
“Permitted laboratory” means a licensed laboratory operating under a permit.
“Phlebotomist” means an individual who procures a blood specimen by venipuncture, arterial puncture, or capillary sampling.

“Physician” means a doctor of medicine or a doctor of osteopathy licensed by the Maryland State Board of Physicians and a doctor of podiatric medicine licensed by the Maryland State Board of Podiatric Medical Examiners.

“Physician of a practice” means a physician employed, salaried, or otherwise engaged to operate or function as a member in a medical practice, even if the physician does not have an ownership interest in the practice or the practice's laboratory.

“Physician office laboratory (POL)” means a medical laboratory operated by a single practice of medicine, individually or collectively by one or more physicians, that is used solely as an adjunct to the care of patients of the practice.

“Point-of-care laboratory (POCL)” means a laboratory operated as part of, or in association with, a medical care facility, such as a hospital, nursing home, community health center, health maintenance organization, county or municipal health department, or a pharmacy.
“Practice” means:
An individual physician licensed to practice medicine in the State; or

A medical partnership, professional association, professional service corporation, or medical corporation of two or more physicians licensed to practice medicine in the State and sharing facilities, personnel, income, or business expenses.
“Precision” means the agreement of results among themselves when a specimen or sample is tested multiple times.
“Pre-field evaluation” means the assessment of an analytical system before it may be used in a mobile or temporary laboratory.
“Primary standard” means a comprehensive general standard or set of standards that:
A laboratory must meet to obtain or retain a license to operate; or
An individual must meet in order to examine gynecologic cytology specimens.
“Principal sanction” means the denial, suspension, or revocation of a license.

“Proficiency testing (PT)” means evaluation of an individual's ability to perform laboratory procedures or tests within the PT program's defined limits of accuracy through analysis of unknown samples distributed at periodic intervals by an external source.
“Public health laboratory” means a public, nonprofit laboratory solely owned and operated by or for the State, a county, or a municipal health department located in the State.
Quality Assurance.

“Quality assurance” means a system of established written policies and procedures designed to monitor, review, evaluate, and improve the ongoing and overall quality of the preanalytic, analytic, and postanalytic aspects of laboratory testing.
“Quality assurance” includes but is not limited to practices involving:
Patient preparation;
Specimen collection, labeling, processing, and transport;
Quality control strategies, practices, and results;
Record keeping;
Personnel training and competency;
Continuing education;
Proficiency testing;
Remedial and corrective actions; and
Analytical system evaluation, validation, and verification.
Quality Control.
“Quality control” means established written policies and procedures designed to ensure reliable laboratory testing by monitoring, reviewing, and evaluating the analytic aspects of laboratory testing.
“Quality control” includes but is not limited to policies and procedures that detect, monitor, review, and evaluate the:
Accuracy and precision of the analytic phase of a testing process;
Changes in the chemical, electronic, optical, or mechanical components of an analytical system;
Deterioration of reagents, materials, or supplies used in a testing process; and
Personnel practices during a testing process.
“Quality control test” means an examination performed on an external test sample that:
Is not part of the analytical system;
Contains a known quantity of the analyte being tested;
Is similar in its physical characteristics and constituents to patient specimens tested by the system; and
Reacts with all system components in the same way as a patient specimen.
“Rare disease” means:
A disabling, chronically debilitating, or life-threatening disease or condition that has fewer than 200,000 affected individuals in the United States, which is equivalent to:
A prevalence of fewer than one individual per 2,000 individuals in the population; or
An incidence of fewer than one affected individual per 10,000 individuals in the population;
A disabling or life-threatening disease or condition that is listed as a rare disease by the National Institutes of Health Office of Rare Diseases; or
A disabling or life-threatening disease or condition in which more than 200,000 individuals are affected if:
A subpopulation of the disease or condition is equal to the prevalence standard for a rare disease in §B(64)(a) of this regulation; or
The incidence of the disease or condition is fewer than five affected individuals per 10,000 in a defined community.
Rare Disease Test.
“Rare disease test” means a test that is:
Performed on a specimen obtained from an individual in order to determine or evaluate whether the individual has a rare disease or condition;
Based on a single method using one sample of a specimen to produce the test result; and
Not routinely offered or performed by a medical laboratory permitted by the Department.
“Rare disease test” includes a test with multiple clinical or health evaluation uses such as:
Newborn screening;
Carrier screening;
Predictive testing;
Disease diagnosis; or
Disease prognosis.
“Reliable” means that the quality of a test result meets the quality standards for the preanalytic, analytic, and postanalytic phases of the testing process as set forth in COMAR 10.10.06.
“Remeasurement” means repeating the measurement of an analyte.
“Sample” means a substance, constituent, or material intended for use in quality control, proficiency testing, or another aspect of a laboratory's quality assurance program.
Sanction.
“Sanction” means an action that the Secretary may take to effect statutory or regulatory compliance.
“Sanction” includes a principal sanction and an alternative sanction.
Secretary.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Health or the Secretary's designee.
“Secretary” includes the Office of Health Care Quality as a designee.
“SOPM” means a standard operating procedure manual.
“Specialty” means a scientific field of study within a laboratory subdiscipline, such as compatibility testing within the subdiscipline of immunohematology.
“Specimen” means material collected from the human body and intended for laboratory testing.
“Standard” means one or more specific technical, procedural, fiscal, or other requirements that a laboratory or individual must meet to comply with this chapter.
“Subdiscipline” means a scientific field of study within a laboratory discipline, such as bacteriology within the discipline of microbiology and dermatopathology within the discipline of pathology.
Survey.
“Survey” means an on-site visit to a laboratory by one or more employees of the OHCQ to carry out or oversee the regulation of medical laboratories.
“Survey” includes but is not limited to:
Inspection;
Follow-up inspection;
Complaint investigation; and
On-site monitoring.
System Check.

“System check” means a device that verifies all or part of the chemical, electronic, optical, or mechanical components or constituents of a test system to determine if the test system is functioning properly.
“System check” includes chemical, electronic, optical, or mechanical devices, such as a card, tube, or strip that simulates a properly functioning single-use test device.
“System check” does not include a quality control test sample or patient specimen.
“Technical supervisor” means an individual who is qualified to direct medical laboratory testing in at least one laboratory discipline.
“Technician” means an individual who has at least 1 year of experience in a licensed medical laboratory, other than an excepted laboratory, and who has earned:
An associate degree in a laboratory science or medical laboratory technology from an accredited college or university; or
60 semester hours of academic credit, including 24 semester credit hours of science that include:
6 semester hours of chemistry, and
6 semester hours of biology.
“Technologist” means an individual who:

Possesses a bachelor's degree in a chemical, physical, biological, or clinical laboratory science or in medical technology from an accredited college or university and has at least 1 year of full-time laboratory experience in the discipline in which the individual performs tests;
Received a passing score in the United States Department of Health and Human Services proficiency examination for clinical laboratory technologists; or
Meets the technologist qualifications set forth in 42 CFR §493.1491, which is incorporated by reference in Regulation .04 of this chapter.
“Temporary laboratory” means a medical laboratory located at a temporary testing site, such as a health fair or shopping mall, for fewer than 30 days in 12 consecutive months.
“Test” means a medical laboratory examination, analysis, procedure, or preanalytic, analytic, or postanalytic phase of a testing process.
“Testing event” means an occasion when a health awareness test is offered or performed on a specified date at a temporary laboratory.
“Testing personnel” means an individual or individuals employed or otherwise engaged by a laboratory to perform medical laboratory tests.
“Total number of tests” means all tests performed by a laboratory in all disciplines in the previous calendar year.
“Unsatisfactory proficiency testing performance” means failure to attain the minimum satisfactory score for three of four consecutive proficiency testing events.
“Test System” means the instructions, instrumentation, equipment, and reagents necessary to perform an assay or examination that generates test results.

“Validity check” means a procedural, testing process, or analytical verification of proper performance of one or more analytical steps performed by the test system operator, built into a test system, and carried out by a test system to detect environmental damage or interfering substances that may have affected the device or the results of the testing process.

para.text: The OHCQ. The OHCQ shall conduct surveys, as set forth in this subtitle, of laboratories that obtain or retain a license.
Surveys. The OHCQ shall:

Conduct or oversee an announced or unannounced survey of a laboratory at any time during its hours of operation to assess compliance with applicable sections of Health-General Article, Title 17, Subtitles 2 and 5, Annotated Code of Maryland, and this chapter; and

Examine, as part of a survey, a laboratory's facilities, equipment, quality assurance records and procedures, operating procedures, personnel and personnel records, proficiency testing, patient reports, and other records and files pertinent and subject to this subtitle.
Issuance of Licensing Documents. The OHCQ shall:
License a person to operate a laboratory by issuing a letter of exception or permit when the laboratory is in compliance with the applicable standards set forth in this subtitle;
Issue a license that includes the:
Name of the laboratory;
Name of the licensee or laboratory director; and
Name of the laboratory owner.
Issue a license that designates:
The classes of services, that is, disciplines, provided;
The tests or examinations offered; or
Both §C(3)(a) and (b) of this regulation.
Administration and Information Management. The OHCQ shall:
Maintain a list of licensed laboratories;
Document information regarding denial, suspension, or revocation of a license and submit this documentation to the Secretary;
Monitor the proficiency testing performance of a laboratory required to participate in proficiency testing; and

For tests that are not CLIA waived, impose alternative sanctions and initiate actions leading to imposition of principal sanctions against a laboratory under the appropriate provisions of this subtitle.
Recommending Excepted Test Status.

para.text: Eligibility.

An individual directing a POL or POCL who offers to perform or performs tests limited to one or more excepted tests may obtain a letter of exception instead of a permit to offer to perform or perform those tests.
An individual eligible for a letter of exception shall:
Be qualified as a laboratory director as set forth in 42 CFR §493.1405, including:
Being a doctor of medicine or doctor of osteopathy licensed in the State and having laboratory training or experience appropriate for the testing performed; or
Holding an earned doctoral, master's, or bachelor's degree in a chemical, physical, biological, or clinical laboratory science or medical technology from an accredited institution;
Provide evidence of training in the performance and interpretation of excepted tests and be licensed in the State as a:
Nurse midwife;
Nurse practitioner;
Physician assistant;
Chiropractor;
Podiatrist;
Dentist; or
Pharmacist; or
Be clinical staff who:
Meets the qualifications set forth in COMAR 10.47.01.06D;
Is employed by a substance abuse treatment program that is certified or accredited in accordance with COMAR 10.47.04.03; and
Is authorized to order tests to detect the presence of controlled dangerous substances on patients enrolled in the substance abuse treatment program.
A person operating a temporary medical laboratory to perform health awareness tests, regardless of testing site location, is not eligible for a letter of exception.
Excepted Tests. A POL or POCL operating under a letter of exception may perform one or more CLIA waived tests.
Reporting Requirements for Whole Blood Lead Testing on a CLIA Waived Analyzer.
The blood tests for lead shall:
Be reported under this regulation in the format approved by the Maryland Department of the Environment; and
Include the information required by this regulation.
The blood tests for lead to be reported shall include the following information:
Demographic information including:
Name, including first, last, middle initial;
Date of birth, sex, and race;
Complete home address at the time the blood specimen was drawn including house or apartment number, street, city, county or town, zip code, and state;
Telephone number; and
Parent or guardian name;
Residential status, for example, whether parent or guardian owns their home or rents;
Type of specimen, either venous or capillary, and date the specimen was drawn;
Clinic or practice name, address, and telephone number;
Draw site name and address, if different from clinic or practice;
Blood lead level in micrograms per deciliter; and
Any additional information as may be required by the Maryland Department of the Environment.
Regulatory Requirements. An individual required to obtain a license to operate a laboratory who chooses to operate under a letter of exception shall:
Obtain, complete, and file an application as prescribed in Regulation .04 of this chapter; and
Comply with good laboratory practices that include:
Following the manufacturer's instructions for instrument or test system operation and test performance;
Having a procedure manual describing the processes for performing tests and reporting patient test results;
Performing and documenting quality control procedures using applicable levels of control materials each day of testing;
Performing and documenting that remedial action has been taken when problems or errors are identified;
Documenting lot numbers of all quality control reagents used; and
Performing and documenting test system function for instruments with internal quality controls on each day of testing.

section.heading: Letter of Exception and Permit — Administrative Procedures.

para.text: Application — Filing.
Except for a laboratory eligible for a multi-site license as set forth in Regulation .01D(3)(b) of this chapter, a person shall apply for a license for each laboratory location.

A person holding a license to operate a laboratory in the discipline of chemistry or health awareness testing is not required to obtain a separate cholesterol testing permit to conduct cholesterol testing at a temporary laboratory site if the licensee complies with the requirements applicable to a temporary laboratory as set forth in this subtitle.
A person shall complete and file an application for a license using forms provided by the OHCQ.
A person shall complete on the application a description of laboratory services, which includes but is not limited to:
Types of tests performed or to be performed;
Total number of tests performed or to be performed annually, excluding tests for quality control and proficiency testing; and
Qualifications of personnel who direct, supervise, and perform laboratory testing.

The laboratory director shall sign the application forms attesting that the information provided is accurate and that the laboratory is or will be operated in accordance with the requirements and standards required in this chapter.
Application — Evaluation and Billing.
The OHCQ shall review and evaluate an application in accordance with the standards and requirements of this subtitle to determine if an application is complete.
The OHCQ shall review and evaluate an application in accordance with the standards and requirements of this subtitle to determine if the laboratory is eligible for a:
Letter of exception;
Letter of exception — limited testing for rare diseases; or
Permit.

Application — Denial of License. If the OHCQ determines that a laboratory is not in compliance with the requirements of this chapter and therefore cannot be issued a license, the OHCQ shall provide to the laboratory:
A written statement of the grounds on which the denial is based; and
The opportunity to:
Amend and resubmit the application; or

Request, in writing, an opportunity for a hearing as provided in the Administrative Procedure Act, State Government Article, §§10-201—10-226, and Health-General Article, §§17-210 and 17-509, Annotated Code of Maryland.
Notification Requirements. A licensee shall notify the OHCQ within 30 days of a change in laboratory:
Ownership;
Name;
Location; or
Director.
Amending a Permit. Except as prescribed in §D of this regulation, a licensee holding an unexpired permit who wishes to amend it shall:
Submit a written request for amendment to the Secretary; and
Obtain written approval from the OHCQ before implementing the amendment.
Non-Transferability. A license is not transferable between laboratories, directors, or locations.
Letter of Exception. A person applying for a letter of exception for a POL or POCL shall submit an initial application.
Letter of Exception — Limited Testing for Rare Diseases. A person applying for a letter of exception—limited testing for rare diseases for a laboratory shall submit an initial application.

para.text: Primary Standard. A licensee operating under a permit shall ensure that the laboratory participates successfully in PT, when applicable, for each test or analyte in each of the following disciplines, subdisciplines, and specialties:
Microbiology, including the subdisciplines of:
Bacteriology;
Mycobacteriology;
Mycology;
Parasitology; and
Virology;
Immunology, including the subdisciplines of:
General immunology;
General serology; and
Syphilis serology;
Chemistry, including the subdisciplines of:
Blood gas analysis;
Endocrinology;
Routine chemistry; and
Toxicology;
Genetics, including the subdisciplines of:
Biochemical genetics;
Cytogenetics; and
Molecular genetics;
Hematology, including the subdisciplines of:
Coagulation testing; and
Routine hematology;
Pathology, including the subdiscipline of gynecologic cytology;
Immunohematology, including the specialties of:
ABO group and D(Rho) typing;
Unexpected antibody detection, that is, antibody screen;
Antibody identification; and
Compatibility testing; and
Forensic toxicology limited to job-related alcohol and controlled dangerous substances.
Discipline Standards.
General. A licensee operating under a permit shall ensure that the laboratory meets the applicable PT standards set forth in this chapter and in 42 CFR §§493.821493.865.

Gynecologic Cytology. A licensee operating under a permit to perform gynecologic cytology shall ensure that the laboratory enrolls and maintains successful participation in a cytology PT program approved by CMS.
Job-Related Testing.

A licensee operating under a permit to perform job-related testing for alcohol or controlled dangerous substances shall ensure that the laboratory enrolls and continues to participate satisfactorily, when applicable, in one or more of the programs listed in §B(3)(b)(e) of this regulation.

Screening Tests. A licensee operating under a permit to perform screening tests for job-related alcohol and controlled dangerous substances shall ensure that the laboratory enrolls and participates satisfactorily in:
The American Association of Bioanalysts (AAB) Urine Toxicology Screening survey;
The American Association for Clinical Chemistry/College of American Pathologists (AACC/CAP) Forensic Urine Drug Testing Screening survey; or
Another program approved by the Secretary as set forth in Regulation .03 of this chapter.

Confirmation Tests. A licensee operating under a permit to perform confirmation tests for job-related alcohol and controlled dangerous substances shall ensure that the laboratory enrolls and participates satisfactorily in:
The AACC/CAP Forensic Urine Drug Testing Confirmatory survey;
The federal Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration's Federal Workplace Drug Testing Program; or
Another program approved by the Secretary as set forth in Regulation .03 of this chapter.
Blood Alcohol Tests. A licensee operating under a permit to perform tests for alcohol in blood shall ensure that the laboratory enrolls and participates satisfactorily in:
The AACC/CAP survey for whole blood alcohol or serum alcohol, or both; or
Another program approved by the Secretary as set forth in Regulation .03 of this chapter.
Hair Analysis. A licensee operating under a permit to perform tests for a controlled dangerous substance in hair shall ensure that the laboratory enrolls and participates satisfactorily in:
The State of Florida's P.T. program for drug testing in hair; or

Another program that possesses standards set by the Secretary or that are equivalent to the State of Florida's PT program for drug testing in hair and is approved by the Secretary as set forth in Regulation .03 of this chapter.

The Secretary may not issue a license to operate a laboratory that examines gynecologic cytology specimens if the laboratory does not enroll and participate satisfactorily in a cytology PT program approved by CMS.
The OHCQ shall evaluate an individual's PT performance as set forth in 42 CFR §493.945.

Primary Standard. A pathologist or cytotechnologist who examines gynecological cytology specimens from individuals in this State shall participate satisfactorily in an annual cytology PT program approved by CMS.
Laboratory Standards.

A licensee operating under a permit to examine gynecologic cytology specimens shall ensure that each pathologist and cytotechnologist who examines gynecologic cytology specimens participates in a cytology PT program conducted by the Department or approved by CMS.
A licensee employing an individual who has failed a second testing event in an annual PT cycle shall:

Prohibit the individual from examining gynecologic specimens and provide or secure remedial training and education in gynecologic cytology for the individual, which training and education includes examination by the individual of gynecologic specimens in the individual's area of failure; and
Document the individual's completion of education and training.
A licensee employing an individual who has failed a first or subsequent PT event and who does not obtain mandated retesting or retraining, or both, shall:
Immediately remove that individual from a position of examining gynecologic cytology specimens for the purpose of reporting diagnostic test results to a health care provider; and

Provide written notice to the OHCQ within 30 days after being informed of the individual's last test failure that the individual is no longer examining gynecologic cytology specimens for the purpose of reporting diagnostic test results to a health care provider.
Individual Standards.

A cytotechnologist or pathologist who examines gynecological cytology specimens shall participate in an annual PT event that involves the examination of a 10-slide or 20-slide test set as set forth in 42 CFR §493.945.
An individual passes a testing event and performs satisfactorily in PT when the individual scores at least 90 percent on a 10-slide or 20-slide test set.
An individual fails a testing event and performs unsatisfactorily in PT if the individual:
Scores less than 90 percent on a 10-slide or 20-slide test set; or
Fails to take a scheduled retest without prior Department approval.
An individual who fails the annual testing event shall take a second test with another 10-slide test set:
Within 45 days after receiving notice of a test failure; or
At a later date with prior Department approval.
An individual who fails a second test shall:
Cease examining gynecologic specimens immediately upon being notified of the second failure;
Complete at least 40 hours of remedial training and education in gynecologic cytology that includes examining gynecological specimens in the area of failure;
Complete the required training and education in a laboratory that operates under a:
State permit for in-State laboratories; or
Certificate issued by CMS in the subdiscipline of gynecologic cytology for out-of-State laboratories;
Document the required remedial training and education when completed, using a form provided by the OHCQ, and submit the completed form to the OHCQ;
Schedule and take a third test with a 20-slide test set within 30 days of completing the required remedial training and education; and
Begin examining gynecologic cytology specimens only after the OHCQ informs the individual that the individual obtained a passing score on the third test.
An individual who fails a third or subsequent test shall:
Complete at least 35 hours of documented, formally structured, continuing education in diagnostic cytopathology that focuses on the examination of gynecologic preparations;
Document the education when completed, using a form provided by the OHCQ, and submit the completed form to the OHCQ;
Schedule and take a subsequent test with a 20-slide test set within 30 days of completing the required continuing education; and
Begin examining gynecologic cytology specimens only after the OHCQ informs the individual that the individual obtained a passing score on the test required under §C(6)(c) of this regulation.
An individual who fails a first or subsequent testing event in an annual PT cycle and who chooses not to complete mandatory retesting or remedial training, or both, shall:
Immediately cease examining gynecologic cytology specimens and notify the OHCQ of this in writing; and
Reenter the PT process at the point where the individual previously chose to withdraw from the testing process, if the individual decides at a later date to satisfy PT requirements.
